The problem with being insecure (atleast in my case) about your looks is the halo effect. As an attractive being youre perceived as healthy, successful, intelligent, open-minded, friendly etc. but if youre in that role you always fear that you dont come up to those expectations. So good looks (might) lead to insecurity about your body AND other attributes as well. I do know that I am attractive or at least above average but that does not help me at all. I am insecure about my intelligence and keep my mouth closed when I talk to a group of friends or strangers as I fear being exposed, I fear being reduced to my looks and I fear feeling that deep core feeling of sheer stupidity that I carry around every day. Looks arent everything and they will make some experiences even worse.

People, for fucks sake, looks really arent everything. Yes, a lot of you guys are right, they do matter, just not in the way that you guys think. Looks are poweful, they are a way to portray yourself in front of others. The way you dress, the expressions on your face, the way you stand, can all give a sense of power. But looking just like whats cool and popular and unrealistic, ruins that sense of power you could hold. Wearing makeup just because you think youre ugly, which youre not, and wearing clothes that you think will give you a pass to feeling accepted, even if you fucking hate them, is not what it means to be good looking. Going on diets so you can have a body that even models are probably making themselves miserable, and maybe even lying to you to have ruins it too. Models are pretty, yes, but they dont define what it means to be beautiful. Being pretty is a one sided term, only looking to the unrealistic, big picture standards of a being. Being beautiful means to be you, to be human. To feel, to be imperfect. Have you ever realized how you react to these two different terms? A typical reaction to being pretty is that you might feel good because it gives you a sense of false hope, and false joy. But it doesnt feel authentic. However, when youre called beautfiul, doesnt it sound more authentic? Genuine? Real? Dont you feel a better sense of joy when you hear the word alone? Thats what I mean. Dont beat yourself up for something that you cant control. You can still have good looks. You just need that sense of power in the way you hold and view yourself. It will change you. Truly. Looks dont define who you are. Theyre just the blank canvas for all of youre enigmatic colors! Sorry this is so long/: I hope it helps though.

Anyone who has ever been unattractive can tell you that looks do matter. A lot. I was a very ugly duckling who grew into my looks in my early 20s. There is no comparison between how I was treated before and after. It was night and day.

The difference between how youd imagine people would treat a disgusting alien lifeform and how people would treat royalty or someone magical. When youre attractive and dress to conceal it (no or intentionally bad makeup, frumpy clothes, bad posture) the way people treat you feels MEAN but in reality, its just the absence of everyone bending over backwards for you. Its how every average person is treated, and better than ugly people are treated.

The world is so kind to me now, but Im still bitter. I havent forgotten how people treated me when I wasnt attractive. I was the same person. I was actually probably a better person when I was ugly: I was kinder, less vain, less judgmental. I tried to do good in the world. And none of that mattered. All that matters is how you look.

People see others in two ways, Consciously and Unconsciously. What they "see" consciously, is most often what they present to the World, (for numerous reasons), and is basically a Facade, a Construct. What is "Seen" Unconsciously, is most Often what a person reads about the other person and is usually the more accurate of the two views.

When the two views are relatively close, the viewer feels more comfortable, but when there is a large difference between the two, "Alarm Bells" are triggered in the viewer's Mind and they Instinctively know that something is wrong . . . what is seen doesn't 'Ring True'.

There certainly doesn't seem to be a middle ground on this TED post. Commenters seem to be very supportive or very critical. And with over 25k comments its certainly a push-button issue.
I for one, think at the very least she's being honest. And at one point somewhat self-deprecating, when she tells about how phony the "walking pose while looking back over her shoulder at nothing" (paraphrasing) feels to her. I think her point is, she's telling us she doesn't think she's anything special, and yes, she knows she's getting paid well for something she didn't "earn."
It seems most of the negative comments dwell on this last aspect. Who's to say she didn't made a decision to take advantage of her situation so she could have the wherewithal, financial and otherwise, to pursue avocations and activities important to her, that actually move her soul and help others? As long as she doesn't mistreat other humans on her life's journey, who are we to criticize her for this?
Beautiful people, especially women, do have more doors open to, and for, them. Conversely, the toughest path is probably that of what most of us would call the physically unattractive woman. There's a TED talk from Lizzie Velasquez that addresses this last issue. After watching Cameron and Lizzie's presentations I came away with the same feeling, that I no longer saw the surface smiles, frowns, eyes, chins, hair etc. but the human underneath.
I call that a win-win for all of us.

Factually, yes, looks aren't everything. Looks can't compensate wholly for a lack of intelligence/intellect, personality, drive, ambition, good values, morals, etc.
BUT looks do make life easier. People are generally more attracted to you initially. It helps gain an edge in social interactions and relationships. Makes people like you more, esp if you're even mildly kind and interesting. Good looking people also tend to struggle much less with self esteem issues, esp when growing up. You naturally feel better about yourself when you look good and get feedback on it often. You feel desired and wanted. Maybe it leads to more romantic experiences which bolster even more self confidence. You feel more like a "man" or "woman," and sexually confident. It may be shallow at times, but attention is attention. We all crave it to some degree.

Looks might not seem like everything, if you are spectacularly good looking.  This reminds me of millionaires telling people that money isn't everything.  When you have a ton of a precious commodity, it is easy to take it for granted, even though you are one millionth of a percent of all of humanity.  Be happy you were born with spectacular beauty, don't be ashamed of it.  Own it.

To those making comments along the lines of "Millionaire: Money isn't imlortant" you have missed the point. A millionaire is the most qualified to make that judgement. They may be lonely, depressed or struggle in different ways. One thing that people forget is that money can isolate you as people envy and resent you. You can also become a target. Money isnt everything but poverty is a real problem.

I applaud her for playing her cards well and being humble while doing so, however diluting her accomplishments via perceived social benefit, whether real or imigined, does very little to encourage personal responsibility, and instead serves to cripple the inner strength of so many who believe they were dealt a bad hand. Being treated better because youre better looking is called natural selection and it persists in every animal species. This is not a problem, this is what makes us survive. Without it there would be a reverse evolution and eventually extinction

Having it all genetically will open you doors to every media business, choosing the right doors will lead you to the best outcomes, the best outcomes are followed by peoples perceptions, perspectives, opinions, criticisms. If you don't have it all genetically, you are fucked in that particular department, you are still followed by peoples perceptions, perspectives, opinions, you will never reach the best outcome, you have limited doors, choices are limited, the outcome is in a spectrum of bad to great, a thoughtful approach could lead you to a great outcome, pursuing a great door will lead you to great outcomes, great outcomes are followed by peoples perceptions, perspectives, opinions.

The conclusion I have is:

Genetic Lottery is like having a Low Level Character in a Video Game, with every tool to make you one of the best in you Inventory. You will be judged for that, envied by that, possibly exploited by that, the fact you have those tools puts you in a spotlight, everyone desires that position you have by nature, everyone wants a piece of it.

Not winning Genetic Lottery is starting fresh with no tools, you grind your way to a position, you will never reach certain positions because people have tools you don't have and surpass you very early, but if you reach a great position in life, you will be in a spotlight, people will desire what you managed to achieve, everyone wants a piece of that achievement, you could still get exploited.

I was anorexic as a teenager, and I STILL struggle with food avoidance and laxative abuse. I work out at least 3 hours a day. I drink as much water and as many meals as I can to avoid calories. I obsess over every label. I did organ damage to myself. I had a chance to start a local modeling career, but I said NO because I don't want to be the woman another girl looks at and punishes herself to try to become.

Yes, you were dealt a good hand, but it was your choice what you did with it, and you chose to get up there and be just another cog in the wheel, another reason why this vicious cycle will never end. For as long as the thinnest and prettiest women keep getting up there for the world to look at, girls like me -- that 12 year old looking at Seventeen Magazine -- will keep hating themselves for not being able to be that.

People, we PAY these women to be FAKE and then we ADMIRE them! Why?! Why do we do this to ourselves, to our little girls? If she really cared about her privilege so much, she would use it to END this obsession with false beauty ideals, not continue them for her benefit.

I can totally understand why persons in her industry are among the most insecure. Because in "show-off" business (as Jamie Lee Curtis so aptly puts it), your reputation is based on and you earn your living by looking good. In an industry where there's always a search for a new "lottery winner", it places significant pressure on those already in it because they're constantly expected to maintain an image and a persona that is not real. This many times spirals into serious mental health issues.

Unfortunately, the world never validates their cries because we, also living in a superficial world, grow up believing that persons with symmetrical faces have it all and any issue they have is just a whine. Good TED talk! So interesting that this talk has been watched over 25 million times (while I write this reply in 2020, 7 years later). If I compare that with other TED talks about different topics which had less views it has something to say that so many people are interested in looks. It's something so obvious and something so sought after that it is really alarming. I think social media (like YouTube, Instagram) add to that for a big part, even from the time there were movies, but essentially it's something from all centuries. In the ancient Greek world people seek beauty as a way to honor the Gods by making statues of naked men and woman.

And finally, I'm a model too (just parttime), so yes you get more chances if you are good looking and friendly. But unhappiness is an inside job and trust me, insecurity is a lot more troublesome than looking good on the outside if you can't be happy with it. Also most people are so superficial thinking that models are just only looks and not people with feelings and brains. It can also be hard because people find it hard to approach you. So in a way you're kind of isolated. That's more worse than just being normal. You see, if people say girls only come to you because of how good looking you are, but not love you for who you really are, what benefit is that in the end?

I think more than this misleading and kind of sensationalistic title, what she was trying to say was not that looks arent everything, look at me, Im good looking, so I would know. No. She even cites her own experiences with getting away with trouble to demonstrate how looks play a very important part in how a person judges you. What she meant to say was that appearance is a superficial part and that it doesnt actually guarantee what most people with image problems think it would guarantee: a better self esteem. Shes stating, when she says models are the most physically insecure people out there, that the looks cant provide you the thing youre actually lacking: a positive outlook on your own self, and that statement can be somewhat relieving and terrifying at the same time, because it means that the problem is not something you can simply change with surgery, diet, makeup or whatever. Instead, its something only to be solved with much time and dedication, by believing you, in the way you are, are enough

My mood and level of connection makes a difference in how people treat me also, so I have dated, had multiple people I liked or loved who were interested in me, and who wanted to marry me.  In fact I counsel people on how to bring out their most attractive and convey it in mood, attitude and energy or connection, so I believe strongly that looks are not everything, but looks ARE also a big factor...no question. Yea, right! Obviously looks are (not) everything - until you lose your looks and have to get by without them like normal people do. Hearing a beautiful person talk about the down side of being beautiful is like hearing a rich person complaining about the downside of having too much money. Obviously the benefits of being rich outweigh any and all  inherent disadvantages, otherwise the rich people would give away all of their money and live as pauper monks (or nuns). How many rich people actually do that? Not many. Likewise, if being beautiful was really such a burden, then all of the pretty people would let themselves go, gain weight, let their hair and hygiene go wild, quit buying make-up and expensive clothes, and just become plain and ugly like the rest of us. Do any of the beautiful people actually do that? Maybe for a day when they cover up with a hat and sunglasses to disguise themselves so that they can go shopping in peace, but no one deliberately tries to permanent disfigure their appearance because they cannot stand all of the unearned, positive attention that they are getting anymore because of their pretty face, and just become a regular slob like the rest of us plain looking peasants. I was quite conflicted by this talk...on the one hand I think she was trying to make a valid point and I could tell she was perhaps a bit nervous of how it would be received. I thought she did a good job, but after reading the barrage of comments I found the whole issue bothering me....sour grapes or a genuine representation of the society we live in??? Either way...we all seem to be pretty superficial don't we?? As Brene Brown would say..she at least had the guts to "get in the arena" and try and make a statement about how SHE has been treated and viewed by others...based on just the one variable of her looks. And yes...I agree we hear a lot of...looks aren't everything, money isn't everything, status and fame isn't what its cracked up to be...etc etc....and it does seem easier to say those things when you've never had to struggle with any of them. It struck me though how many people forgot to mention what I would consider THE most priceless thing that too...is part often of a "lottery"... Or sometimes bad choices rather than the plain and simple genetics and good or bad luck in that department.....NONE of those things matter to me. Because the one thing you need...that nobody seems to acknowledge here...is your health. I GUARANTEE you've never heard ANYONE rich, poor,beautiful,ugly, famous or not...say that GOOD health isn't all its cracked up to be??? Without it there is no way you would worry yourself about all the superficialities of life....because believe me....in my books, being both physically and/or mentally healthy is THE most important commodity in the world. And.....there is beauty in everybody. Be grateful for what you have.

People are more sensitive to race and looks than they are about intelligence because people believe they can become more intelligent. That is not so, you can become better informed, but you cannot learn how to be intelligent. Intelligence on a human is like a boolean and this is important because it's an aspect that can make or break your life.



You will lose your job because you lack intelligence, but your looks are largely insignificant in most industries, and even if you are an actor or model you sometimes still need some degree of intelligence to survive the competition. When you lose your job because of your looks, that is considered discrimination, but you could easily be intelligence impaired and not know about it and no one will think twice about firing you then.


One should never feel guilty about genetic inheritance. When a lion or tiger attack they definitely don't question their superior genes in relation to their prey, their "legacy" is to be at the apex. The universe is not fair, fairness is a human construct.



Humans need 26 fundamental constants in order to try and understand the universe. The human mind is only comfortable with tangible, mathematically precise, and nameable concepts, yet the universe is in flux. Flux means concepts can change, what favours you today may be a disadvantage tomorrow, this challenges you to adapt. Is it common in mathematics for two quantities to have the same value in a complex system? Humans all want to be treated equally, and fairly, this is mathematically impossible, in a utopia perhaps. We are teaching people to be entitled and narcissistic like the universe owes them something. This makes people complacent, and when there is a shift in the forces of the universe (when all you know comes crashing down), it's very hard to recover because you find you are not prepared and not adaptable enough for a new world. If the universe is in flux, we must also be in flux, vigilant, ready for anything at all times!



You can be a part of society, do the things you must do at present, work hard, but don't fall for the illusion that you have made it. Everything you have can be taken from you at any time, ask a Hurricane survivor or a terminal patient, you think that's fair? There is no fairness here, be vigilant and take care of yourself. I would refrain from boasting, and feeling self-important about material things and achievements, these are a useless use of time. Today you may be great, but tomorrow you could be less than ordinary, and the next you can be greater... flux... just keep going about your business discreetly and always vigilant.

While much of what is said is on point, first impression is lasting and much more difficult to change than a simple clothing swap. However, it is the words that she says after we are no longer distracted by appearance. These are what resonate and tell us who she is. For me, my first modeling shoot, I felt it in my gut, much like her, it felt uncomfortable to arch the back and separate the lips as if you are sucking on a tiny penis. For me, it revolted me and really opened my eyes into what modeling really is, exploiting of women who fit into a mold of what we perceive as beauty. That was the last day I ever did modeling, feeling disgusted in myself for being so naive and being used in this rather dirty feeling photo shoot (however, by today standards it would be rated G). If all of this BS stopped, then girls would finally be happy with themselves no longer seeking fashion, makeup and plastic surgery to feel that they are good enough. Today I buy my natural makeup from a friend who has her own business supporting women (busygirlcosmetics), and I buy clothing from fair trade, small businesses. I do not watch movies or TV shows that require women to expose themselves. I no longer support the exploitation and objectification of women and hope that others will open their eyes and see themselves as the perfect beings they are and not give their monies to these corporations who try so desperately to make us all feel less than.

Then why choose to do that job? I understand that if you succeed you can make lots of money , you get to travel a lot , you get to know about fashion and photography etc... But , this industry can be ( and most of the time is ) incredibly toxic. Everything revolves around one's looks. Individuality and genuine confidence are so likely to be eliminated. Nothing matters but the way you look. Nothing. How disturbing is that? No wonder many models feel very insecure even though their actual job is to represent what being beautiful is like. In spite of all these , they choose to profit from that system and contradict their claims on their instagram accounts where they post either photos of them looking perfect or photos of them being their " everyday self " who is still much better looking than the average person. I'm not saying I don't like models , that would be plain stupid , but I see so much contradiction in the messages some of them they convey. In addition , when they say that we must tackle our perception when seeing a photo of a gorgeous model and after the first impression we must think that this photo has been retouched so that the model looks this way , they must take into consideration that  this thinking process can be done only by people who have reached a certain age and ability of critical thinking. When you upload videos on YouTube of your perfect vacation in an exotic island , taking a swim in your perfect body , you have no control over who sees that. Little kids won't think of the process behind this video , they just look at a perfect looking person with whom they share no resemblance. By the time they reach an age to have a more critical attitude towards the concept of the image , the damage to their subconscious and confidence has already been done. The only way to escape that would be to unlearn everything you've learnt about beauty as a child which is a very difficult thing to do... I just can't wrap my head around the contradictions coming out of this industry...

Am I the only one who's sick of hearing the phrase "generic lottery"? It's not as if human souls drop down from the sky, tumbling through a giant invisible plinko board and land in random human bodies. Each person's genes is the heritage their parents chose carefully to bestow them, based on what their evolved instincts and cultural wisdom advised them to choose, over millennia. A person is a transient expression of a much larger chain of events and choices that extend both long before and after themselves. The expression "generic lottery" trivializes the way heritage works by making it sound random, and comes from the idea that heirs of better things have no meaningful claim to what actually is their birthright. "But you didn't choose to be beautiful", the peasant whines, who chose to be resentful. If we were all meant to be equal, nature wouldn't have given us diversity.

Hmm  it was interesting to hear what she had to say. Im someone who in my daily life doesnt actually get noticed all that much... its because I dont usually always wear the right clothing. I dont usually wear makeup. My hair is either up in a bun or flat... and Im NOT a tall blond blue eyed beauty... so by most peoples standards who know me in normal life would not think this way about me.. plus, when I was younger, I struggled with eating disorders. I never really did recreational drugs and Im sensitive to alcohol consumption, so those were not my things, plus Im an introvert and didnt like the party scene. So I guess you can say that food was my drug of choice if I had to pick my poison, that was it. So, I struggled with being overweight a lot of the time, there were times I would work out, lose weight and look nice and curvy, but most of the time, I was not noticed... but those I worked side by side with and associated with were like that. I remembered being compared with them and of course, I never quite measured up to those I was around. I remembered once meeting a man in Italy and one of the ladies I was aquatinted with told me how beautiful Italian women are and if I wanted to impress him, I gotta make myself hotter than I am. I remembered even ex boyfriends I had would make comments on the beauty of those women and not like that about me...  I remembered how awful and ugly I felt in those moments. But I remembered when MySpace came out. A friend of mine wanted me to make a profile. She did my makeup, had me put on some nice shirts etc... and I admit, I couldnt believe what I saw. When others saw me in that light who already knew me, they couldnt believe it. Even an ex landlady of mine tore me down on how these beautiful photos looks NOTHING like me! She kept saying it wasnt me! She was ruthless about it too!! It nearly killed me inside! I remembered wanting to take my own life the next day! Thats how much it impacted me... & I did pay a professional photographer to do something that I never did before in my life, I took some retro pin up photos. No, theyre not the most beautiful amazing photos that someone ever saw... Im not your classic runway by any stretch! But, I got a lot of compliments and positive feedback nevertheless... it made me feel good. It gave me an ego boost. But at the end of the day, I am haunted by those words and the negative feedback of how Im not enough. I have changed my eating habits and work out regularly. I still dont wear makeup,  in fact, I suck at applying it. I still dress down most days and wear comfortable clothes both for work (CMT so I dont like looking fancy) and I work out too. Every so often, I hear about these women who get catered to and spoiled just because their hot. I dont know how to feel about it? Granted, on one hand I do want to be taken seriously, but on another, sometimes I wonder what its like to be a princess or a queen? Yeah, I do wonder what Im missing or missed? But Im that person who never asked nor expected much from anyone. Im too proud to ask for help unless Im truly in a desperate position. It would honestly be awkward for me to get that kind of treatment. I dont know that I would be able to receive it?

I never had self esteem issues and always felt happy with how I looked. always had men tell me straight out that I was beautiful and never had any issues with attracting men so I always assumed that I was an attractive looking woman. I never used it to my advantage, I always found that women were very insecure around me and very jealous so it was difficult to work with women, men always expected me to 'behave ' a certain way! At age 37 I underwent brain surgery to remove an acoustic neuroma brain tumour. the facial nerve was damaged and as a result I have very little movement on the left side of my face causing asymetry and speech issues. After the initial shock  and I couldn't recognise my face I realised how differently people were treating me. It was incredible how differently people treated me. Men do not approach me or talk to me anymore and women don't pay much attention or indulge ,e with the pity party talk. The insecure jealous types were no longer intimadated and let out their real side!   It made me realise how differently people behave around beautiful people and how superficial they can be, I quess hiding the self worth issues they face when they are confronted with some one who has something that they wish for themselves. In saying that I can understand it now, when I see people smile broadly or blink both of their beautiful eye lashes (men and women) I am cringing and wishing dearly that I could do that.I never had self esteem issues before or cared that much about what others thought of me, so I can understand how people who do not consider themselves to be beautiful would begrudge and dismiss someone who does receive alot of attention because of their looks. But I still don't sympathise because it is up to each individual to engage with their own gifts and talents and find their own sense of worth . And stop feeling sorry for themselves and , self pity is a coping mechanism and if you work through it you learn how to self sooth instead!

Thanks for an excellent talk. I am old, and I am from an ancient culture (which at least had ancient wisdom orientation, decades ago). There is saying, which no one listens to any more, that beauty is skin deep.  What that also means is that a man can get prettiest woman in his life, and he will then find out many surprising facts. One that she is not pretty all the time, second that if she gets a cold, she will sneeze and have runny nose, as is expected and not look so pretty, and third that the construction that goes with looking beautiful, at times may become burden for her. To feel truly loved, even the most beautiful woman, would wish to be loved also, when she looks ugly, or when she is without construction. Back in time, when wisdom reigned, people were not instantaneously judged based on looks only. We waited to hear what they say, and what their values are. As humans, we were not walking around on the planet to reduce other humans to judgements,  based on a 20 second look. Yes, we as a society, in America, (may be in other countries as well), we have become that shallow and superficial.

I'm not a model, and I don't consider myself pretty but I am fairly attractive  or so they say (again, I am not really the vain type, don't put on makeup and basically am a wash and wear type of girl who just wants to do boyish things)(though, I think I got admirers and suitors hugely due to my personality, I guess it didn't hurt that I wasn't that bad looking). At first, I enjoyed it. I'll admit that. In high school, I never understood why boys fawned over me and sent me numerous love lettersand before you get irritated hear me out: Yes, it was fun. But when I got older, and moved to professional life, those advances got really ugly. Sexual harassment and sexism etc. left and right and it got to point where when my hair started thinning and graying, I was actually happy and greatly relieved to be spared from all that "superficial" attention because as pathetic as it sounds, it's actually easier to see the REAL people, friends, and situation if every single circumstance wasn't greatly reliant on your looks. I realized that a lot of people who "admired" me, actually thought that was all there is to me, that I looked neat but there was no way I could be smarter than men (sorry, this is just an example, and it's the most common one that comes to mind, I have nothing against men), and there's no way I could hold a directorial position or be intelligent enough to write a script etc. etc. etc. Even if I actually did prove myself time and again, there will always be people who will look at you and give you judgemental stares, and you know they're summing you up based on superficial factors. It was tough. I used to like taking pictures, but it got to a point where I developed a phobia for pictures of myself because it reminded me of the sheer overpowering vanity of the world. When I started speaking my mind, the boys who used to like me would shame me. It's all a very shallow game, really. The game of physicality. I know no matter how sincere, it will always sound hypocritical, but I guess what she's trying to say is: if attention is all you want, sure good looks are a blast. But if you are the type of person who values more than that, like a person's attitude and mind, and the depth of character, and doing good, and all the truly beautiful things on the inside etc, it kind of sucks to always have a person judge you first and foremost based on your looks. And then stop there.

The fact that a person is born with a particular (ostensible) advantage does not mean that they are in some general way "advantaged."  When you look closely at people's lives you will almost always find there some advantages and some disadvantages.  The "advantage" narrative is a false narrative.  In fact it is little better than an excuse.   And counter-intuitively, the ostensible advantage is very frequently its own disadvantage as well.  For example, the son of a billionaire will never be able to take satisfaction in being self-made or even in succeeding at anything.   Think that motivates?

The title's misleading. She's acknowledging how much looks affect our lives, while recognizing that the way you look is completely superficial. The whole talk is her explaining how good looking people are born with the deck stacked in their favor, and how she benefits from that. There is a reason people who are physically less attractive struggle when it comes to dating; it is because they are filled with self pity, jealousy, bitterness and entitlement, all of which are extremely unattractive traits. And because of their overall mentality, they make no effort to improve the parts of themselves that they have control over, and instead give up at the first hurdle, which pretty much makes them losers hiding behind excuses (such as losing the genetic lottery etc).


On the other hand, those people who take charge of their lives, and focus on improving every aspect of their attractiveness that they have control over, will often find it easy to attract partners. When you develop your confidence and self esteem, and the personality traits that are attractive, you will significantly increase your value. No one wants to go out with a loser who is filled with self pity and complains all the time, but we do find winners attractive, those people who are genuinely happy and positive, and couldn't care less how they compare to other people.


Put simply, there are plenty of changes that most people can make to increase their attractiveness, but until they past their loser mentality (and all of the negative, unattractive traits that come with it), they will never be attractive, and as a result they will never be happy. And the longer you wait until you start making the changes, the more of your best years you will waste feeling sorry for yourself. Just because you weren't born with a perfect face, doesn't mean you are a loser, but if you let your imperfect face be your excuse, then you will behave like a loser, and other people will view you as a loser.

The reason why so many models are not women of color? Light physics.
The darker something is, the less light it reflects. Thus, the less detail is shown. Now apply that to people. If you have a dark skinned model and you have to use more light in order to bring out their features, then you end up washing out the lighter colors of whatever they may be wearing. It's just light physics. And, if it's supposed to be about the clothes, why do they even use "pretty" models in the first place? Stick someone in one of those morph suit things and dress them. Her point is that even if you WERE "beautiful" (which is a fabricated idea) you still wouldn't be happy. Models are insecure everyday. You might be insecure every day. She's not complaining about her looks, she's making a point about how those looks are portrayed and perceived. Cameron Russell won the "gene lottery" and so everyday people worship her (which she did nothing to deserve), and the people in the photo industry exploit her. Models have no rights, and being the subject in a completely staged photo doesn't give you confidence. It doesn't show any skill. But people hate on her if she says anything negative about her life because they STILL believe "if only they were beautiful". How about "if only I were confident" or eventually "I AM confident". Beauty doesn't ignite confidence all by itself.
I love this quote from Susan Tanner:
"I remember well the insecurities I felt as a teenager with a bad case of acne. I tried to care for my skin properly. My parents helped me get medical attention. For years I even went without eating chocolate and all the greasy fast foods around which teens often socialize, but with no obvious healing consequences. It was difficult for me at that time to fully appreciate this body which was giving me so much grief. But my good mother taught me a higher law. Over and over she said to me, You must do everything you can to make your appearance pleasing, but the minute you walk out the door, forget yourself and start concentrating on others. "
I love that. Let's forget ourselves and focus on our personality and education, and let's love others and not care about their appearance.

Hi my name is ella rose, I am 5 foot 4, naturally amazing body, white, small nose, blue eyes. And I was cheated on by my boyfriend by someone who was much uglier than me. After the break up, she was hired at my job and I had to work with her and it hit me, it was never about her looks that made him fall for her. She had such a huge personality and so many friends that cared about her and life going on. And I was just dead lonely, with my thoughts and sadness. My social skills were so rusty because I was so depressed from the break up and I felt like I was not enough. I didnt deserve to be apart of anything. When people invited me to things I would spend hours stressing over what to wear and staring at my hair and then breaking down crying that I couldnt go. And I didnt know why I was like that because I knew I was prettier than most people yet I was scared of being hurt. I wasnt comfortable in my own skin. I didnt want to be me. My family never cared about me. I was never proud of my life. I ended up cutting my hair really short, because I obsessively dyed it different colors. I need help. I feel like I close to dying. its been like this for 1 year and 6 months. I set goals to get better. And yet I feel hopeless. And I HATE that all it took for me to get this bad was for one stupid boy to cheat? I hate myself.

There are more downsides to being pretty than she mentions.
Whenever I see a girl or guy who I think is extremely pretty or handsome I automatically think that they are going to be cold and mean. I think they are going to act stuck up or act like and a-- hole. I definitely don't treat "pretty" people with more respect, I veer away from them. What good is being pretty if people are going to assume you're not kind?
What happens if you built your whole identity off of being "pretty"? When you get older and you don't look as pretty, you may struggle with your identity.
If you're pretty, people automatically assume you are not smart. People don't often take what you say seriously.
"Pretty" people might have a significant other who only likes them superficially. I always noticed how the people I knew that were more attractive were in tumultuous relationships whereas the people who weren't stereotypically pretty were in happy committed relationships. I believe it's because they were able to find relationships that were built off of more than just looks.
I am not denying that pretty people receive more privilege in the world. I am saying there are more negative sides to being pretty than she talks about.
I think the only thing we can do it to feel beautiful from the inside and treat people with equal respect.

Many good and true points.  Many are beneficiary of a system and/or plain luck.  Other's are victim's of a system and/or bad luck.  We have been guilty of oppression and should work towards preventing oppression.  The grass only seems greener on the other side.  Why not make the grass green on both sides.  I agree, and good solid advice.   But, with the devil being in the details it becomes much easier to only imply the source and solutions to the problem.  The tactic goes like this: Lets state a legit fact in detail quickly followed by: ....and thus is caused by A.  And A is obvious and can be derived from my experience, which can obviously be projected upon the population as a whole.  To that process, I disagree.  To the implied assertion: Make it into claim and support it with argument.  Allow for counter argument (not straw men arguments).  That is honesty.  That is how lasting change will occur.

I am a 51 year old wheelchair user from birth. Thumbnail pic is me, age 50, when taken. I grew up knowing I fit the white standard of beauty. At the same time I was made very aware that I was not supposed to. Disability placed me at the heart of a basic societal conflict. Disability is both feared, & undesired. It in no way reflects or meets any standard of beauty. Disability from the societal view or narrative, is perceived as something to be fixed, overcome, or mercifully done away with. I am the embodiment of both high value, & no value. White privilege, & fear / oppression. I am a disabled woman. I would have it no other way. It is a defining characteristic. A bedrock of identity. Much like, my brown hair. Blue eyes. Sarcastic wit, & innate talent / ability to sing. Disability is neither positive or negative. It simply is. All of these contradictions help shape the person I am. I love being me. Beauty is powerful. It is only one kind of power, however. It is neither deep, or lasting. Life is not what happens, to you. Your reactions, create your reality. We are all a mass of contradictions. What we choose to do with them, is what matters. Finally, someone can become more or less, beautiful. Depending on what you find, as you get to know them. Regardless of what you look like. If you are confident. If you like, & accept yourself. It comes across, & you allow others to do the same.

This is a good presentation. She's is basically describing the superficial side of life, in my opinion. "Superficial" as in "external"; people can make judgements of a person from the outside, however they will never know what is really going on on the inside of that individual's mind. I'm a half decent looking woman and have had a complete mixture of behaviours from people: women looking at me like they want to kill me, women noticing me and being positively genuine, men yelling harassment at me, men looking at me intensely then purposely laying into me, and men being complete gentlemen to me. Of course I'm talking about people who I don't know who I run into whether in the street, store or at an event I've been invited to. None of these people know me and I've noticed that many seem to form an instant opinion. But that very small number who haven't have become great friends or at least a tiny positive memory in my life journey. It's important to really take care of our precious minds - this is the biggest lesson I've learned.

I understand the message and applaud the motive behind the speech, but your statistical link is somewhat misguided. I am pretty positive that that study was done in America, where the population is roughly 60% white. Sure, the demographics don't match with the numbers, but with consideration that many non-white citizens tend to be immigrants that came here in the last century or two, and many without a sufficient financial basis to be apart of the lifestyle that models are generally found in, the statistical connection is a weak one at best. I am a very dedicated science major, and the whole foundation on scientific validity stands on objective practices. Look up the major issues with p-values if you would like to scratch the surface of statistical problems in science.

It's not the looks, it's the perception. How you and rest of the world might perceive beauty and humanity? It is true that an attractive person stands out from the crowd, but only at first glance. Seeing that face over and over, makes you get used to that attractive face, same with yourself. You grow up looking at yourself in the mirror as you are, it stays the same until you see new changes as "acne or scars, etc" on your face or when someone points it out for you, which ends up making you aware of yourself. Same analogy with the body, dramatic changes stand out like loosing your weight, even though, you internally haven't changed at all.

Another thought that comes into my mind with how people perceive beauty is by jealousy. In history, stories, myths, etc, the villain is perceived to be the bad one who gets jealous of main character whether it's looks, money, power, talent or other but the villain wants to have these yet can't attain them. This is a very natural yet common phenomenon that might go on till the end of humanity because humans can never sustain themselves and always want more. If our ancestors were perfectly satisfied with their living environments, they would've had never made a recent comfortable world for us. It might also be seen as improvement, innovation, but to me, it's as humans just can't get enough, they would be greedy after more things because that is what's in our nature, what we possess. There are humans who overcome these (monks who shave their heads, strip themselves of a comfortable living to spend life in complete yet peaceful solitude with their beliefs). Same with nuns, and also same in many other religions who teaches to not be greedy and control our nature. In conclusion, the world, society, universe is quite bigger than our imagination, yet majority our stuck with their narrow minds and uncontrollable nature to perceive humans and the world recklessly. It's only good that we make ourselves aware of most scenarios, situations through others stories and struggles to understand ourselves and other humans more like the lady in the video. Keep feeding onto wisdom and understand yourself more to understand others around you.

I saw this when it first came out on YouTube, and I was pretty much questioning her. Like youre pretty, hello, who cares. But, after watching this again, nearly 6 years later, I understand now what she was talking about. I think people can have different takeaways. So, Im just stating my opinion. But for me, at its core this talk is about privilege. Its not about her being a pretty white woman saying shes insecure with her looks. Its about her using her privilege to bring awareness to prejudice. She gave this talk at a time when privilege wasnt aware to mass conscious. The BLM movement wasnt founded till a few months after this Ted, where I got a better grasp of it. A great example is when she compared her being let go for a traffic stop, against the amount of times a Black and Latino will be stopped just for their skin color. As well as when she talked about Tyra and Naomi being less than the 4% in the modeling industry. Theres a discrepancy in how people are treated that she was making a call to using her genetic lottery as that vehicle. So I hope people see that.

How many people have been on dating sites for more than a month, and felt depressed when nobody you like responds to your messages? How many people experience the cycle of rejection again and again, and eventually come to the apparent conclusion that they're ugly? How many people believe they have so much to offer, and even more to say, but feel ignored and rejected because of how they look? How many people are desperate for love, but fake a false sense of security because they believe it's unattractive to admit that they're desperate for it? How many people believe they're ugly and there's nothing they can do about it?...like a cancer of the mind that manifests itself on the outside. How many people watched this video in the hope that they would feel better about their current situation, but throughout thought 'she's pretty, and I'm not?' How many people have resorted to drugs and antidepressants to relieve themselves of these dark thoughts that don't seem to go away? I know I have, and I love you all from the bottom of my heart. I feel your pain. I see your beauty and I admire it in all of its God-given image. I embrace your soul. Even though I don't know you, I connect with you in spirit. The universe has brought us together and will drive away the demons that appear to control it. One day, we will all reach the light at the end of the tunnel, and embrace it, and will appreciate it even more for having walked in blind hope in search for clarity. I love you all.

My looks were average , but I was skinny as a stick.

Here's the take away , the "respect" you feel from the people when you have muscles , that is just your inflated ego , and you enjoy feeding on those praises around you.
Lots of personal trainers and health enthusiasts would disagree with me and throw out facts on the benefits of exercising. But those are just cover ups to hiding the dark truth from you. PS: I never once said that exercising is bad for you. I simply stated the current state of mind of most modern humans in exercising is deteriorating.

I can easily tell the difference between one who is truly exercising just for the sake of health benefits and one who is obsessed with his/her own physical appearance.

Female beauty standards is a major reason why I'm still convinced that people see me as a guy pretending to be a girl. Look, she seems like a sweet and well-intentioned person, but this just is not an appropriate message for her to be delivering. It would be akin to somebody from first world America going to an impoverished, war-torn third world country, and telling the people theremany of whom have witnessed murder, rape, starvation, atrocities unthinkableto feel encouraged, because first world people have problems too, and money, bodily safety, and material comforts are not tickets to happiness. Sure, it may be the technically correct message, in the sense that problems and insecurities are universal, and indeed money cannot buy happiness, but such a statement, delivered from a member of the haves to a population of true have-nots, comes across as not only silly, but deeply inappropriate, insulting, ignorant, condescending, and utterly dismissive of the experiences and narratives of a population with so much more an intimate knowledge and connection with true human suffering. Indeed, suffering, problems, and human insecurities are universal elements of the human experience, but when the vastly privileged appropriate this narrative as their own, when they become lecturers of the subject instead of listeners and learners, the end result can only be further harm, resentment, and alienation. Ms. Russell may very well be a beautiful womaninside and outand I have no contention with that statement, and she may have many important and insightful statements and messages to deliver, but this should not be one of them.

I study attractiveness in my research. It wasn't some I planned to do years ago, just stimbled upon a study that I thought could be replicated and inproved inproved upon. We did the study on perceived attractiveness in women with different hair length. Men like long hair was take-away and also they prefer brunettes on our study. We presented the work at a major conference and had o er 40 people stop by our poster presentation in the one hour time slot. Then a couple of months after the conference. Reuters contacted us to do a piece. I gave the fellow and interview and it went up online. This was in 2003 before social media really hit it big. The following Monday morning my phobe blew up. The student and ai who did the work we discussed by CNN, FOX, and Inside Edition. We were contacted by Men's Health, Prevention magazine, and Abroad to give our study findings and a quote. The student and I interviewed live with Fox and Friends and flew to NYC to be filmed for Inside Edition, and we must have done 30 to 40 radio interviews world wide.
I couldn't believe the public interest in this small, simple study, but people gravitate to anything related to attractiveness. My work as a graduate students years earlier was excellent basic science that I was really proud of. But, there was no inkling of public fascination like with the attractiveness work. And the stereotypes fir attractive people do perpetuate benefits for people rated highly attractive compared to folks of lesser attractiveness. I appreciated how humble and genuine this Ted talk was. When she said she won the genetic lottery, I was hooked to this talk because she acknowledged how lucky attractive people are with regard to serious benefits and perks they have simply by bvb virtue of their appearance. Attractive people statistically make more money, get promoted or receive bonuses more frequently, and have more choices in mating and/or dating opportunities than less attractive people. And for men, height impacts their perceived attractiveness and financial long term outcomes disproportionately to men of shorter stature. In sum, she is right on so many levels, nut our society really reinforces these stereotypes and it's sad.

She had some good points but I dont feel they were presented very well.
1. Image is not the person but we often conflate the two.
2. The fashion images she helped create were largely the doing (talent and abilities) of others and nobody should credit it her with it all. I agree wholeheartedly as I have inside knowledge on this industry.
3. She was at the right place at the right time and given the proper look. What she doesnt acknowledge is this beauty standard is EXPLOITED to sell items. Thats the reason for the model selections. Things are changing now and there are a lot of Chinese models on the runway because China is a big market. That being said, many Chinese go out of their way to be as white as possible. Why? Thats for a sociologist to answer, but that has been the standard raised in the global media/Hollywood et al. for a long time.
4. Just because she is pretty doesnt mean she is happy/have a great life. This is true, we all suffer from the human condition.
But she hasnt lived her full life yet so she doesnt know what she hasnt experienced. It reminds me of the saying of a woman being harassed etc and complaining to her friend.Dont worry says the friend, it will go away soon enough. Female Beauty has a short shelf life. Honestly, sorry if this is harsh, but it was a pretty bad talk. She literally got up there and said she got lucky in her life and career, and goes on to reflect in a very shallow fashion how this is unfair. She then tries to engender sympathy by playing a supposed victim, trying to claim that models like her are "the most insecure" women on the planet with respect to their looks. Are you kidding me? Could she have thought for maybe five seconds about the innumerable number of people out there who are obviously plagued by insecurity in their looks EVERY MOMENT OF THEIR WHOLE LIVES because they are NEVER going to be perceived as attractive? I'm sorry but it takes a lot to make me cry.

What's sad is that this woman is actually quite intelligent, apparently. She graduated from Columbia with honors political science and economics. Probably one of the easier degrees to obtain, but it still requires hard work, and Columbia is not typically easy to get into. But the whole focus of her talk doesn't make sense. She's defined her whole life around modelling, but is trying to encourage people not to judge based on looks? Could her life be a more direct contradiction?

Her takeaway message is, literally: "I hope we all feel more comfortable acknowledging the power of image in our perceived successes and our perceived failures." Thanks for a trivial observation. This would be like someone who inherited all their money coming and doing a TED talk saying "I hope we all feel more comfortable acknowledging the power of inherited wealth in our perceived successes and our perceived failures", then walking off the stage after making a few off-handed remarks about how hard it is for rich people to find "true friends" and to never know if someone is dating you for your money. And without offering any advice or solutions. Did it occur to hear that, God forbid, maybe she could not make her WHOLE FRIGGIN CAREER antithetical to the message she brought? If she thinks it's unfair she should be using her intelligence and work ethic in a different career, or using the success she's had as a platform for something greater. She literally spends like two seconds here discussing racism, for example. If she's had success as a model, go and capitalize on that and make a more meaningful contribution to society, if she thinks judgement of looks is shallow. I have no problem if she wants to be a model, but she's being completely hypocritical, so why should we pay attention to her here? Don't spend your life capitalizing on your looks, come up on stage, say it's unfair, offer no solutions or even the most miniscule interest in remedying the problem, and then just walk off, acting like you have some sort of deep insight into the injustice of the ways of the world. 1 out of 5 stars.

It's easy for everyone to always say that "what matters is on the inside", and "you have to be beautiful on the inside", blah...blah...blah. How about you try one week, ONE WEEK, in the body of someone who didn't even get the chance to grow normally, with proportional dimensions in the arms and legs. There are rare growth disorders out there that will cause your upper arms, for instance, to be shorter by 3-4". You think, " oh, well that's nothing". NOPE, think again. The human brain is hardwired to detect even the smallest of errors in the dimensions of the human body. I should know -- my arms are shorter than they should be, and quite literally, 95% of people notice this within 1-2 seconds of seeing me...and then they stare for as long as they possibly can. It doesn't matter that I have a pretty face, a pleasant personality, or an IQ high enough to finish a degree in Geophysics. I will always, ALWAYS be first judged by those missing inches in my arms. If just one doctor had noticed I wasn't growing properly as a child, I wouldn't now have to live this life of misery. Btw, I live in a first-world country.

I think this was great for her to speak on. The topic isn't if good- looking people get treated better, it's that looks aren't everything. It's giving little girls a more realistic idea of what being a model is really like. The media in Western culture tells girls growing up that how you look is the path to success. This can be so damaging and the effects are usually life-long. It takes someone who looks like their 'perceived ideal' to maybe make them realize looks aren't everything. We need more people like this to tell young girls and women that your brain is your path to success, not your body. The more this message is repeated, the greater likelihood more and more girls will aspire to put their energies and efforts into politics, social justice, medicine, etc. instead of constantly worrying about if their thighs touch and if their make-up looks perfect. Voices like these push against what mainstream media is trying to sell us and it's refreshing. Just because she's a model and just because she is beautiful doesn't mean she should be written off. Everyone should have a voice.

I can see both sides of the argument on this video and technically both are right. On one side its good people like her are coming out and saying that she understands how lucky she is and how its not all perfect, she mentions she is insecure but so are a lot of people who aren't good looking, maybe that's the point?  But also remember she benefited greatly from modelling as anyone would do in her position. Heck she modeled for 10 years! I see why others are angry, modelling from what I have heard tends to pay well (not sure in the beginning though) and doesn't seem to need any qualifications, if you look the part then you're hired. She mentions traveling and getting stuff for free, all the things most people don't get to benefit from. So in reality looks do help and without question most would choose to be attractive to get all those benefits.

I mean this also applies to Instagram models, both this lady and them have one thing in common: insecurity. Cindy Crawford herself said "I wish I looked like Cindy Crawford".

Because both models and instagram models have to worry about their looks, the slightest imperfection can be worrying. I got into the habit of posting instagram photos without any photoshop because I knew if I constructed that image of myself that I would come to hate how I actually look, and maybe that's part of the reason why despite severe acne, I don't feel too insecure. No filters or beauty apps. In addition, I have a partner who finds me attractive and loves me even when I'm not wearing makeup + all the acne scars. If I could find him, you too can find someone who will find you beautiful as beauty is so subjective.

Now, I admire her admission to how standards of beauty, at least in her industry, are based on race. She seems to be very wary of herself and how she has an edge in the industry unlike some people that are too prideful to admit it. I don't believe she, however, that she should be blamed for it as there are beautiful people in the world regardless of race and colour who are simply overlooked by the people who are hiring models in the first place. This model was so young when she started that she most likely never realized the racism in the fashion industry until later on. I do, however, think she should have elaborated more on the struggles that models have in the industry that people may not know about. Being physically attractive can call for a lot of unwanted attention and people who base attraction solely on looks vs personality and compatibility.
She is such a beautiful soul though, isn't she?

If you actually watched this video and have negative comments about it then you're part of the problem she is referring to...  It's refreshing to see someone speak truthfully and insightfully about one of the greatest lies being sold to our society - that being attractive and white makes you better.  She's calling it out and saying it's not true and it's not fair.  She is admitting that she's part of a problem that has been built and created more than one that is natural.   This lie she calls out, being white and attractive makes you better and more worthy, has caused so much suffering for anyone who doesn't fit that description.  The tragedy is that instead of viewing advertising manipulation of images with a more critical lens, we continue to glorify the likes of the Kardashans who have no claim to their fame  other than having money and good plastic surgery.  The majority of young people in this country, in the age of social media, are experiencing extensive anxiety, body dysmorphia, loneliness, depression, and more mental health issues at record levels.  If we could scrub the images being sold to us as desirable and if we could start to honor those with good and kind hearts more - emulate the compassionate rather than the vain and shallow, the world would be a better place for everyone.

To all those commenters who spouted something along the lines of 'looks are everything'/'look at the pretty girl complaining about being pretty'. Here's a story for you. I have a friend (really, it was not me), who was dating an extremely pretty girl. Far prettier than Mrs. Russell. She worked for a larger local company in a non-modeling capacity, but they still used her photo in advertisements and company literature. She was just that dam good looking. But bhe had no interests, not much of a personality, wasn't funny. After only a couple months my friend broke up with her. Her, quite amazing, looks just weren't everything. A couple years later my friend married a much less, by comparison, attractive woman. They've been married for 15 years, have two kids. He's happier with the less attractive woman, because the less attractive woman has more of a personality. Looks aren't everything.

Truly the 'best' things in life are those that you've worked for. Mrs. Russell nails it when she says she 'won the genetic lottery'. This, I believe is the real reason so many 'pretty' women are so insecure. They didn't work for their beauty. You know how we treat our star athletes, we honor them, we worship them, etc. etc.? How would feel tomorrow if you woke up and everyone around you treated you like you were the greatest athlete of all time? Remember, you aren't an athlete, you've never won anything, etc. etc. But people let you cut to the front of the line, the smile when they see you, they buy you drinks, etc. etc. Now image how you'd feel after a year of being treated like the great athlete, again, you haven't ever competed in anything. You know you didn't do anything. You know you haven't 'earned' any of this special treatment. You also know that others around you aren't getting the same special treatment, and many of these people actually are accomplished athletes. After awhile this starts to mess with your mind. Some will feel guilt, for they understand they're getting special treatment for accomplishing nothing. Some will fall prey to hubris and start to actually believe they are the greatest athlete, although deep down they'll always 'know' they are lying to themselves. Knowing you are 'false' leads to insecurity. What if people suddenly find out you're not the greatest athlete? What if they stop caring if your the greatest athlete? What if you are given a promotion at work, based on you being a great athlete, and you are put in a position that's above your head? If we get back to winning the genetic lottery and talk specifically about beauty, insecurity is also generated because at some point you realize you'll get old and the beauty goes away. When the beauty goes away the free ride goes with it. It's like apressure cookerof insecurity, slowly building pressure as the years tick by. While it's hard to 'feel sorry' for really pretty girls, I do. Seeing anyone who'll never be judged for the content of their character, or their actual accomplishments, etc. It's kinda sad. A perfect example is this video. I think Mrs. Russell did a pretty solid job. But I'm betting a lot of the clicks on this video were because of her looks. I bet a lot of the viewers will mostly remember how pretty she was, and not really what she said. And if you read through the comments, you see quite a bit of hate/jealousy/ignorance in response to her looks (not what she said).

I see a few "ugly duckling" stories in the comments.  I have experienced the opposite.  From my teens through my 20's, my world-view was that everyone was kind, nice, compassionate.  I crossed 30, gained weight and looked nothing like the apparently handsome young man I was, and suddenly strangers were not nice and kind whenever I met them - they often glared at me, or worse, ignored me entirely.  It took a few years, but I figured it out.  People were kinder to me as a young, slender, good-looking man, and as I aged and gained weight, their unconscious programming told men and women alike that I had no value and to either hate me or ignore me.  Society is fickle.  Looks are fleeting.  Our harsh society judges us all instantly upon appearance.  Young?  Old?  Attractive?  Unattractive?  Influential?  Wealthy?  In a split-second view, we all consign each other to our respective pigeon holes.  I've begun to lose weight, by the way.  And with each new burst of weight loss, the world is suddenly friendlier to me - more smiles, more 'please', more 'thank you', more people holding the door open for me.  It makes me angry, actually - all of these people, who several months ago would not even acknowledge my presence are suddenly being kind to me again, and I hate the hypocrisy - I am the same man, I just now have a different shell.  We are all so petty.

BTW, the less tall one was, by comparison, no more than "what the cat dragged in" for all she cared about me... Nor am I complaining, just a fact!), yet he was always reticent to admit being one, to anyone he ever met. To those who met him, should anyone ever suggest "you should be a model" he just returned a wry smile and nodded a 'maybe someday...' kind of nod back. Even that wouldn't make him admit. He feared being instantly stereotyped as either unintelligent or unusually vain.

Being not as tall as him, made a huge difference, in the dating years I can absolutely and unquestionably confirm that fact for sure. He could attract girls, back then, in the same way that the rest of us go down to the shops when we're out of milk. He just couldn't understand it when I would go on about how so few were willing even to give me a chance. I had a similar face, but it was those 4 inches of height which ensured that 6th winning number in 'the genetic lottery' - where every single number, bar none, must hit industry requirements, or you will have next to no chance of having that much envied life where you can attract the interest of most others without much problem. yet then fear telling them that you're really just a model, who is paid to show up and take directions when called for. Frankly, it's not just the female models who are insecure, in other words. And, I might add, with very good reason; discounting, of course, the very few who are so vain, they might tell themselves "what others think is what others think... etc."

The irony of it all, is that while you enter on looks alone, it's ultimately all down to either the client's own taste, or what clients want at each casting, which is all that matters. So someone who appears to have it all still might not get booked - despite months of turning up for castings, simply because the look client was seeking each wasted ime, wasn't yours. Anyone who is in any way insecure will find this very difficult, at least some times.

:PS - I had to add this. Modelling is about the only job where you don't necessarily need to be 'discovered', at many agencies you even don't need to show up for a formal interview to be signed, nor even need a book (photos of your previous shoots) with you to be recruited, and in some cases, it really could be just your self and anyone else accompanying, in off the street, whenever you could be bothered to visit, will be enough to become signed. Never pay for test photos up front - if you are that rare that you have it you have it. And any agency which charges prospective models for photowork before signing is almost certainly not worth the time of day. Looks are and alas will be the only currency which matter inside those doors, and for the rest of your comparatively short career. No references needed. Not even timekeeping references! Dress to impress? Forget it.

BTW, anyone who can't make the gigs, won't get rebooked, as after looks tick all boxes, a reputation for professionalism is what matters next. Also, just as in real life, where some people wouldn't find a supermodel attractive and viceversa, each agency has varyingly different requirements in the looks dept., to the next. So, prospective models could give up disheartened, after being rejected by 5 in a row, without realising that the next three could just as easily want to grab you! When I knew about this, it worked this way but I've no idea if it's the same or any different now - when much younger I witnessed similar in two different countries) If you're what they want, you could turn up, whenever you like, and ask to see one of their bookers, casual as you like, in teeshirt and jeans, and the receptionist will either look at you, and say something like, "sorry our book's full here, you could try another agency..." OR, will say this (which is, or was..., good news) "could you take a seat for five minutes please", after which the person with arguably one of the few better jobs in the industry will stride from nowhere, and do their stuff; chances are, you will be walking out not too long later, as good as signed with them, before you've even walked out. What people likely envy about it all, is that there is (bar all nepotistic roles) no other better paid job, which requires no cv, no references and no need to dress up, at any pre-arranged time just to be initially signed, either.

It sounds narcissistic, but I know people think Im pretty. I didnt think that when I was younger, it was fed to me. Even knowing all of these pitfalls, when I am out for the evening, my gaze will still fall upon a pretty woman, and a pretty woman's eyes will still look straight though me and come to rest upon my friend, who is better looking than me. The small cold comfort  I have is that I'm sixty and the whole silly game is soon to be over for me. I wish I'd been strong enough not to play. I have known people who were.

A Columbia University student graduates that majors in political science and economics with honors decides to deliver a speech derived from personal experience in an industry that judges you for factors you cannot control as opposed to your intellect and your skill set.

Spoiler, the Columbia graduate is Cameron Russell.

The point I believe she is getting at is what you and society perceives as value. Without knowing who the Columbia graduate that I previously stated was, it's safe to assume most people believe this person can be of value to society. But being 'pretty' by society's standard is also supposedly valuable as portrayed by media, right? She said it herself, when little girls tell her that they want to become models when they grow up, she asks them, "Why?" In our society, pretty people get is easy, but that doesn't make you any less valuable. If Cameron had a different physical appearance, would that take away from her intellect? From her value? I don't think so.

I am told all the time that I should be a model for my looks. I have gone to big cities like Miami and Chicago and have been asked by actual models if I was one too. I am not one btw. Because of my looks, I get free stuff (food, clothes, technology) and compliments just about everyday but she is right, it is definitely not peaches and cream. As already mentioned, I get ignorant comments about being smart, pretty, and black all at once. I get unwanted touching like butt grabs by strangers (I was actually threatened to be beaten by a man who I told to never inappropriately touch me again) and unexpected shoulder massages by coworkers. I get rude stares by other women, untrue gossip by jealous people, and hated by women for looking this way. I had a few bullies in HS that I never even had a full conversation with; they hated me for my looks, my style, and the fact that others liked me for it. I am also insecure, I see in black culture that thick thighs and big butts are in. I see that big hips and breasts are in. Long bouncy hair and straight white teeth are in. Well I have gaps in my teeth and coffee/tea stains. I have small hips, long legs, a small waist but with a big booty. My bf calls it slim thick. But definitely not thick like the video girls though! I have short kinky curly hair and 90% of my body resembles that of a skinny white girl with this models body type...so in the black culture, I feel less than everyday because my body type is not ideal to them. In the general society, many men dont give me a second look regardless of prettiness because I am black. Many only give me a second look because I AM black and they want to know how it is to be with a black girl. Dating sucks because people always want to be with you for the wrong reasons.
Okay here is my point....There are many pros and cons to being what you are, NO MATTER what you are. She has pros and cons for being the ideal human, I have pros and cons for being me and so does everyone else in life. But as long as you stay true to WHO you are, dont worry about anothers opinions about WHAT you are. It may hurt you financially or socially for a little bit but keep pushing and the bully at the top will eventually give way. I am a strong black female, I dont care if someone pushes me , I will push back until they stop.

brilliant vid . Below is an extreme essay about some of the few topics in the comment section. Don't judge me I was bored. Everyone is at a certain point to be fair.
(Note there may be errors or what not. But grammar Nazis are not welcome so be gone)




Then I went to the comment section where two types of people dwell the positive and the negative.
Allow me to point out some things I spotted in the comment section and simplify them.
Indeed we all have heard the "looks are not everything" . This is true. Personality and other factors 'should' be at the top of the priority list without a doubt . Of course aesthetics play a role to a certain degree but let's put it into a situation. Let's say a person isn't particularly attractive based on your preferences but had many more positive qualities, there should be a compromise to a certain degree as to weather you'd start a relationship with them or not. In today's society that's not the case, most people are judged strictly on appearance nowadays and people who are supposedly 'unattractive' usually are not given the chance to show their other qualities to make up for what they may be lacking. The word it's self 'unattractive' strictly depends on personal preference as well since 'beauty' can be something very different depending on the person e.g what one may see as unattractive another may see it as attractive. Media is designed to influence people on what attractiveness looks like or just simply show what the majority believe is attractive, in reality it's just down to preference and most people would do well to make compromises in appearance for other characteristics but unfortunately most humans are not like that and blame biological traits or whatever that bullshit is ( your a human with a complex brain and capable of making decisions not based strictly on biological traits fucking use it ). compromises would allow anoyone to have a chance with anyone they wished instead of being completely rulled out due to appearance. If people were willing to make compromises and not judge people on just appearance the world would indeed be a better place.

- 'What Is Beauty?'
https://www.facebook.com/notes/david-mitchell/what-is-beauty/380240772580/

Growing up in a 21st Century
For our young, growing up in a 21st century world where titillation by media and electronic devices jockey for attention, have ad peddlers often presenting life in a tinselized sort of way. This life style of care-free, showy pretense can be viewed as personal choice but at the social cross-roads, where actions touch the lives of others is a different (and prohibitively limiting) matter.

With a rising behavior for texting while driving, social bullying and the sociopath seeking fame by horrific destruction of life (also on the rise), what words of wisdom can we share with this generation? On the subject of seeking social acceptance, my advice for the Generation 'Me'); start with ground-zero, examine ones heart and how it can be motivated in being receptive to the hearts and outward expressions of others. Its a connected world, we must learn to work and live together and the best teacher is by example. Just some thoughts gathered from listening to and speaking with many seniors over the years.
